DOC.HEAD: Excel, Union Reach Agreement on Meatpacking Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Excel Corp. and the union that represents many of the company's workers have reached an agreement aimed at reducing injury rates at Excel's meatpacking plants. Both parties said the agreement is unique because Excel, based in Wichita, acted voluntarily. ``Obviously we hope that the rest of the industry will respond as responsibly as Excel has,'' said Al Zack, spokesman for the United Food and Commercial Workers in Washington. ``We've gone through a lot of battles with other companies just to prove that problems existed.'' Battles with other packers, notably IBP and John Morrell & Co., have resulted in the Occupational Safety and Health Administration levying more than $10 million in fines. The union's complaints have centered on injuries caused by repetitive-motion stress. Zack said provisions of the agreement were similar to those ordered by OSHA in the IBP and Morrell cases. The agreement will first be implemented at Excel's Plainview, Texas, plant and later expanded to beef-processing plants in Dodge City; Friona, Texas; Nebraska City, Neb.; Schuyler, Neb.; Sterling, Colo.; Marysville, Calif.; a beef-distribution center in Philadelphia; and pork-processing operations in Beardstown, Ill., and Ottumwa, Iowa. The union represents about 8,600 workers at those plants. Zack said the union had brought safety issues to Excel's attention at the Plainview and Ottumwa plants. The company responded with a proposal, rather than denying that injury problems existed, he said. Under the terms of the agreement, Excel will hire an ergonomic consultant and other medical personnel, and union members will be trained as monitors to survey work areas, spot symptoms of repetitive-motion stress and recommend solutions. The program will involve testing of production flows and equipment, experimental work stations, worker training on the causes and prevention of injuries and revised procedures to treat and rehabilitate injured workers.
